repnme.cdata!:
Solomon Islands - Health Sector Support
            Program Technical Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Health Sector Support
            Program (HSSP) Technical Assistance Project for Solomon
            Islands were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was also moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: the project team took the right
            decision to shift to a Technical Assistance Loan (TAL)
            focused on the core building blocks for the HSSP support for
            one sector program; enhanced Development Partner (DP)
            coordination; and joint monitoring and strengthening of
            Ministry of Health and Medical Services (MHMS) budget and
            planning systems. This perhaps took too long because of the
            collective regional commitment to a Sector Wide Approach
            (SWAp) without being clear on what the up-front readiness
            conditions should be. Another lesson is that enhanced
            supervision and implementation support is needed,
            particularly in fiduciary management for projects, in
            countries such as the Solomon Islands, no matter what the
            scale of the project. Procurement and particularly financial
            management support from specialized staff in the Bank was
            inadequate and typically not coordinated with review
            missions. The separation of team responsibilities within the
            Bank for different parts of the supervision process in the
            recent past has reduced the effectiveness of the Bank in
            supervision of projects. A key lesson is that the Bank needs
            to develop a better business model for undertaking fiduciary
            supervision in small countries where it cannot justify
            locating fiduciary specialists in-country. Another lesson is
            that persistence on the need for core Bank requirements
            sometimes pays off. The executing agency often complained
            strongly about the Bank's insistence, under the
            project, to develop a procurement plan and follow it. The
            MHMS now openly recognize that this is precisely what they
            need for their own government development budget and are now
            planning one for their 2013 development budget because of
            significant delays in 2012 (and earlier) due to a lack of planning.

Solomon Islands - Health Sector Support
            Program Technical Assistance Project

repnme.cdata!: Solomon Islands - Health Sector Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The status of the health sector in
            Solomon Islands deteriorated significantly from 1998-2003
            during a period of civil conflict known as the tensions.
            The health sector has continuing problems, with some
            indicators remaining among the worst in the Pacific. Solomon
            Islands is still experiencing challenges related to both
            technical quality of services and the capacity of the health
            system to deliver services effectively and efficiently.

23193267.trustfund:
TF091233-SB HEALTH SECTOR SUPPORT
            PROJECT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE

repnme.cdata!:
Solomon Islands - Health Sector Support
            Program Technical Assistance Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Health Sector
            Support Program (HSSP) Technical Assistance Project for
            Solomon Islands is to improve the institutional capacity of
            the Ministry of Health and Medical Services (MHMS) in the
            areas of public expenditure management and sector
            performance monitoring. Such capacity development will be
            critical to the overall success of the HSSP in improving
            health services delivery and outcomes. There has been
            considerable delay in project implementation and although
            the grant became effective on July 14, 2008, with the
            exception of the purchase of a new photocopier, no
            expenditure had occurred. The Ministry acknowledges the
            delay was mostly due to lack of understanding of the project
            arrangements within the Ministry itself and to a high
            turnover of senior staff in 2009. As outlined in the aide
            memoire from the April mission, good progress is now being
            made as a result of assistance under the grant and Ministry
            staffs are committed to maximizing the Bank's technical
            support. The initial withdrawal application is being
            submitted and further withdrawal applications will follow
            regularly. The contract for the financial management
            specialist, management training and other assistance will
            occur throughout the calendar year 2011. Extending the grant
            to December 31, 2011 will enable effective use of grant
            resources as outlined in the attached revised procurement
            and training plans.

9413497.trustfund:
TF030796-JAPAN CTF - FY06 GENERAL: EAP
            (ALL COUNTRIES IN EAST ASIA AND PACIFIC/A,TF055712-PF III PI-EASHD,TF091233-SB HEALTH SECTOR SUPPORT
            PROJECT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE

repnme.cdata!:
Solomon Islands - Health Sector Support
            Program Technical Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Solomon Islands' Health Sector
            Support Program Technical Assistance Project's
            development objective is to improve the institutional
            capacity of the Ministry of Health and Medical Services
            (MHMS) in the areas of public expenditure management and
            sector performance monitoring. Such capacity development
            will be critical to the overall success of the Health Sector
            Support Program (HSSP) in improving health services delivery
            and outcomes. The project's first component is: Public
            Expenditure Management. This project component will
            contribute technical assistance to complete the first
            rolling sector Medium Term Expenditure Framework (MTEF), and
            improve national MHMS and provincial health planning and
            budgeting systems and procedures, building on work done
            during preparation, so that priorities are set within a
            known resource envelope and linked to expected results. The
            second component is: Sector performance monitoring. This
            project component will provide technical assistance to
            improve the sector-wide program's Monitoring and
            Evaluation (M&E) framework to focus on a core set of
            indicators covering the key dimensions of sector performance
            along key dimensions. The third component is: training and
            capacity building. This component will strengthen the
            management capacity of senior managers and provincial health
            directors to be more effective in strategic planning and
            execution. It will also finance part of the MHMS strategic
            human resource training plan.

docna.cdata!:
Solomon Islands - Health Sector Support
            Program Technical Assistance Project
